prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We just aim to detect the 870 um continuum, so the default continuum freqency setup is used.

In order to maximize the detection efficiency, we do not want to the majority of our sources to be resolved. But we still need a good enough resolution so that close pairs or mergers are not misidentified as single objects. Based on a mass-size realtion evolution measured from the CANDELS survey (van der Wel+2014), star-forming galaxies at z~4 with M* ~ 10^{11} Msun have sizes (half-light radius) ~ 3kpc, correspoindg to 0.4". We thus securely aim at a 0.7" resolution, which will leave most of our sample unresolved. This resolution also roughly matches that of the deep Ks-band imaing available in these fields.

We detemine typical 870um fluxes for galaxies in our sample through a median stacking analysis on existed Laboca and Scuba 870 um images, which yields S870 = 0.75 +/- 0.2 mJy (after correcting by 15% for clustering). So we require a RMS~0.15 mJy to achieve a 5sigma detection for most of the sources in the sample.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our current understanding on the cosmic star formation history at z > 4 is primarily based on UV-selected galaxies. A critical question is then whether we are missing a significant population of massive, UV-faint galaxies. By crossmatching HST/WFC3 and IRAC data in the three CANDELS-Herschel fields, we perform a systematic search of galaxies which are bright in IRAC but are not detected in the WFC3 H band, i.e., H-dropouts, which are likely at z > 4 where the H band probes the rest-frame UV. In total, we identify 64 H-dropouts down to [4.5] < 24, corresponding to M*~10^{10.8} Msun at z > 4. Both photometric redshifts and stacked infrared SED suggest that most of them are at z > 4, with LIR~2*10^{12} Lsun. These galaxies likely represent 30-40\% of the most massive galaxies at z > 4, but were completely missed in previous studies based on either UV or near-infrared selected samples. An ALMA 870 um census is crucial to confirm individually that they are high-redshift dusty sources, and explore star formation properties for this unique sample, which is essential to have a complete understanding of massive galaxy formation in the first 1.5 Gyr of the universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
